channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: 'Everybody's got bills to pay': The price of a prolonged government shutdown
item.description: The government shutdown's economic impact has been limited so far, but experts warn the costs -- and its burden on Americans -- could grow with time.
item.content:encoded: The government shutdown's economic impact has been limited so far, but experts warn the costs -- and its burden on Americans -- could grow with time.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Hakeem Jeffries says public pressure will force Congress to extend ACA subsidies
item.description: The Democratic House Minority Leader tells NPR Americans will pressure Congress to extend Obamacare subsidies as they realize their health care costs are going up.
item.content:encoded:
The Democratic House Minority Leader tells NPR Americans will pressure Congress to extend Obamacare subsidies as they realize their health care costs are going up.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Obed Manuel

item.title: Karine Jean-Pierre on why she left the Democrats — and calls herself independent
item.description: In her new book Independent, former Biden press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre writes that party infighting, bias and disloyalty drove her to leave the Democratic Party.
item.content:encoded:
In her new book Independent, former Biden press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre writes that party infighting, bias and disloyalty drove her to leave the Democratic Party.

(Image credit: Bronson Arcuri/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Majd Al-Waheidi

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Analysts say the longer the shutdown drags on, the costlier it could become, tensions between the U.S. and Colombia continue to rise, authorities continue their investigation into the Louvre heist.
item.content:encoded: Analysts say the longer the shutdown drags on, the costlier it could become, tensions between the U.S. and Colombia continue to rise, authorities continue their investigation into the Louvre heist.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Mariners fall short in Game 7, remain MLB's only team without a World Series trip
item.description: A late three-run home run by the Toronto Blue Jays ended the Seattle Mariner's longest postseason run and their World Series hopes. The Blue Jays will now face the L.A. Dodgers in the World Series.
item.content:encoded: A late three-run home run by the Toronto Blue Jays ended the Seattle Mariner's longest postseason run and their World Series hopes. The Blue Jays will now face the L.A. Dodgers in the World Series.
item.dc:creator: Vaughan Jones

item.title: Grant Hill, NBA on NBC game analyst, talks about the start of the new season
item.description: The NBA season tips off Tuesday with a doubleheader. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with NBA hall of famer Grant Hill about the season's key storylines and the return of NBC as official broadcast partner.
item.content:encoded: The NBA season tips off Tuesday with a doubleheader. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with NBA hall of famer Grant Hill about the season's key storylines and the return of NBC as official broadcast partner.
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Middle East Institute's Natan Sachs on Israel and the future of the ceasefire deal
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Natan Sachs with the Middle East Institute about the future of the ceasefire deal from Israel's perspective.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Natan Sachs with the Middle East Institute about the future of the ceasefire deal from Israel's perspective.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Sudan's El Fasher nears collapse amid famine and relentless strikes
item.description: After 18 months under siege, El Fasher in Sudan's remote Darfur region has become a famine-stricken, bomb-blasted city on the brink of extinction.
item.content:encoded: After 18 months under siege, El Fasher in Sudan's remote Darfur region has become a famine-stricken, bomb-blasted city on the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Fire truck shortages leave some communities waiting longer for emergency response
item.description: In some communities, fire crews are delayed -- not by distance, but by a lack of equipment. Higher costs and supply chain issues means some departments have to wait years for new trucks.
item.content:encoded: In some communities, fire crews are delayed -- not by distance, but by a lack of equipment. Higher costs and supply chain issues means some departments have to wait years for new trucks.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Roth

item.title: Japan's parliament elects first female prime minister
item.description: Sanae Takaichi became Japan's first female prime minister Tuesday. Her election comes at a time of upheaval in Japanese politics.
item.content:encoded: Sanae Takaichi became Japan's first female prime minister Tuesday. Her election comes at a time of upheaval in Japanese politics.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Kuhn
